aberrant.example: When the financial director started screaming and throwing food at his co-workers, the police had to come in to deal with his aberrant behavior.
aberrant.meaning: markedly different from an accepted norm

abstruse.example: Physics textbooks can seem so abstruse to the uninitiated that readers feel as though they are looking at hieroglyphics.

acerbic.example: Most movie critics are acerbic towards summer blockbusters, often referring to them as garbage.

adamant.example: Civil rights icon Rosa Parks will forever be remembered for adamantly refusing to give up her seat on a public bus--even after the bus driver insisted, she remained rooted in place.

admonitory.example: At the assembly, the high school vice-principal gave the students an admonitory speech, warning them of the many risks and dangers of prom night.
admonitory.meaning: serving to warn; expressing reproof or reproach especially as a corrective

apocryphal.example: The web is notorious for sandwiching apocryphal stories between actual news.

blatant.example: Allen was often punished in school for blatantly disrespecting teachers.
blatant.meaning: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious

bumbling.example: Within a week of starting, the bumbling new waiter was unceremoniously fired.
bumbling.meaning: lacking physical movement skills, especially with the hands

burgeon.example: China's housing market is burgeoning, but some predict that the growth is merely a bubble and will burst much like the U.S. real estate bubble of 2008.

confound.example: Though Harry loved numbers, he found calculus confounding.
Americans often confound sweet potatoes with yams, and refer to both vegetables by the same name.

construe.example: The author's inability to take a side on the issue was construed by both his opponents and supporters as a sign of weakness.

contingent.example: A small contingent of those loyal to the king have gathered around the castle to defend it.
contingent.meaning: a gathering of persons representative of some larger group

contingent.example: Whether the former world champions can win again this year is contingent upon none of its star players getting injured.
contingent.meaning: possible but not certain to occur

copious.example: In midsummer, there are copious popiscle stands at the beach; in the winter, there are none.

decorum.example: You will obey the rules of decorum for this courtroom or spend the night in a jail cell, said the judge to the prosecutor.

denigrate.example: someone Count Rumford denigrated the new theory of heat, demonstrating that it was wholly inadequate to explain the observations.
denigrate.meaning: charge falsely or with malicious intent; attack the good name and reputation of

discrete.example: What was once known as Czechoslovakia has since split into two discrete, independent nations.
discrete.meaning: constituting a separate entity or part

eradicate.example: I tried eradicating the mosquitos in my apartment with a rolled up newspaper, but there were too many of them.

espouse.example: As a college student, Charlie espoused Marxism, growing his beard out and railing against the evils of the free-market.
espouse.meaning: to adopt or support an idea or cause

exacting.example: Though his childhood piano teacher was so exacting, Max is thankful now, as a professional pianist.

exalt.example: The teenagers exalted the rock star, covering their bedrooms with posters of him.

exonerate.example: The document clearly indicated that Nick was out of the state at the time of the crime, and so served to exonerate him of any charges.
exonerate.meaning: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges

expound.example: The CEO refused to expound on the decision to merge our department with another one, and so I quit.
expound.meaning: add details or explanation; clarify the meaning; state in depth

forthcoming.example: The President announced that the senators were about to reach a compromise, and that he was eager to read the forthcoming details of the bill.
forthcoming.meaning: available when required or as promised

forthcoming.example: As a husband, Larry was not forthcoming: if Jill didn't demand to know details, Larry would never share them with her.
forthcoming.meaning: at ease in talking to others

hackneyed.example: Cheryl rolled her eyes when she heard the lecturer's hackneyed advice to "be true to yourself."
hackneyed.meaning: lacking significance through having been overused

iconoclastic.example: Jackson Pollack was an iconoclastic artist, totally breaking with tradition by splashing paint on a blank canvas.

idiosyncrasy.example: Peggy's numerous idiosyncrasies include wearing mismatched shoes, laughing loudly to herself, and owning a pet aardvark.
idiosyncrasy.meaning: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual

ignoble.example: In the 1920s, the World Series was rigged--an ignoble act which baseball took decades to recover from.

implacable.example: Win or lose, the coach was always implacable, never giving the athletes an easy practice or a break.
implacable.meaning: incapable of making less angry or hostile

implausible.example: The teacher found it implausible that the student was late to school because he had been kidnapped by outlaws on horseback.
implausible.meaning: describing a statement that is not believable

incorrigible.example: Tom Sawyer seems like an incorrigible youth until Huck Finn enters the novel; even Sawyer can't match his fierce individual spirit.

indifference.example: In an effort to fight indifference, the president of the college introduced a new, stricter grading system.
indifference.meaning: the trait of seeming not to care

ingratiate.example: Even though Tom didn't like his new boss, he decided to ingratiate himself to her in order to advance his career.
ingratiate.meaning: gain favor with somebody by deliberate efforts

intransigent.example: Despite many calls for mercy, the judge remained intransigent, citing strict legal precedence.
intransigent.meaning: unwilling to change one's beliefs or course of action

largess.example: Uncle Frank was known for his largess, so his nephew was sad when he did not receive a present for his birthday.

laudable.example: To say that Gandhi's actions were laudable is the greatest understatement; he overthrew an empire without violence.

myopic.example: The company ultimately went out of business because the myopic managers couldn't predict the changes in their industry.
myopic.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

opaque.example: The meaning of the professor's new research was opaque to most people, so no one asked any questions.
opaque.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

ostentatious.example: Matt wanted to buy stone lions for front of the house, but Cynthia convinced him that such a display would be too ostentatious for a modest house in an unassuming neighborhood.
ostentatious.meaning: intended to attract notice and impress others; tawdry or vulgar

pedantic.example: Professor Thompson was regarded as an expert in his field, but his lectures were utterly pedantic, focused on rigorous details of the most trivial conventions in the field.
pedantic.meaning: marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning especially its trivial aspects

petulant.example: When Ed first met Ruth, he didn't realize she was so petulant, but now that they are three months into their relationship, Ed feels a day doesn't go by in which she isn't whining about some minor issue.

pragmatic.example: Rather than make a philosophical appeal to the Congressmen, the Speaker decided to take a far more pragmatic approach, making small side-deals that would add votes to his bill.
pragmatic.meaning: guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory

provincial.example: Maggie's enthusiasm about her high school teams seemed provincial to her college classmates, all of whom were following a nationally ranked college team.
provincial.meaning: characteristic of the a limited perspective; not fashionable or sophisticated

pundit.example: Steven Pinker's credentials are unquestioned as a pundit; he has taught at MIT and Stanford, teaches at Harvard, and has published a number of influential books on cognition, language, and psychology.
pundit.meaning: someone who has been admitted to membership in a scholarly field

reconcile.example: Peggy was unable to reconcile her kind friend Jane with the cruel and merciless character Jane played on television.

refute.example: No one could refute his theories or propositions, and that is why he was esteemed by all his colleagues in the philosophy department.
refute.meaning: prove to be false or incorrect

soporific.example: Although the professor is brilliant, his bland monotone gives his lectures a soporific effect.

temperance.example: Welles wasn't known for his temperance--he usually ate enough for two and drank enough for three.

tortuous.example: Because the logic behind McMahon's side of the debate was so tortuous, his audience came out either completely confused or, worse, feeling they'd been tricked.
tortuous.meaning: marked by repeated turns and bends; not straightforward

underscore.example: While the hiking instructor agreed that carrying a first aid kit could be a good idea under certain circumstances, he underscored the importance of carrying enough water.

unscrupulous.example: In the courtroom, the lawyer was unscrupulous, using every manner of deceit and manipulation to secure a victory for himself.
